access.description: The registered URL (costs-and-limitations) 301-redirects to costs-and-requirements via Yoast SEO Premium. The redirected page loads as static WordPress HTML with the EHI export section visible near the bottom without any accordion or JavaScript interaction. The data dictionary link points to client.rojihealthintel.com/helpfiles/ehi-export/patientexport.yml, but this file currently returns 404. The file was only recoverable via the Wayback Machine (single snapshot from April 23, 2024). The site uses Sucuri WAF and Cloudflare CDN but no anti-bot blocking was encountered.

products.name: Roji Clinical Data Registry

product_context.description: Roji Clinical Data Registry is NOT an EHR. It is a CMS-approved Qualified Clinical Data Registry (QCDR) and quality reporting analytics platform delivered as SaaS. The company (formerly ICLOPS, founded 2002) has been a CMS-qualified registry since 2008. The product aggregates clinical data from existing EHR systems (via flat files, FHIR, HL7, and custom formats) into a patient-centric database for quality measure calculation/reporting (MIPS, MVPs, APP, ACOs), episode-of-care cost analysis, population health analytics, and provider benchmarking. It is used by ACOs, health systems, and medical groups that already have their own EHR systems — it is a secondary analytics layer, not a primary system of record for clinical care. The certified criteria (c)(2)-(c)(4) for CQM import/calculate/report/filter confirm its core function. It has no patient portal, no billing/RCM system, no scheduling, and no document management. The product stores aggregated clinical data points, quality measure results, claims-derived cost/utilization data, and patient demographics — not full clinical records.

export_approach.description: The EHI export is a native JSON export of the registry's patient-level data. The vendor states: 'Single patient and population exports are available free of charge for users with patient level access in JSON format.' The data dictionary is a JSON Schema (draft-07) document describing a PatientData object with sections for Demographics, QualityMeasures, PatientRisk, Conditions, UtilizationProvider, Episodes (with cost data), HistoryClaims, Immunizations, Outcomes, and Medications. This is a database-native export of the aggregated registry data — not FHIR, not C-CDA. The export is appropriate for this product's scope: it exports the quality/analytics data the registry stores, which is itself derived from upstream EHR data.

documentation_quality.description: The documentation consists of a single JSON Schema file (patientexport.yml, misnamed — it's JSON not YAML) that defines the structure of the patient export. The schema provides field-level detail with field names and data types, but has no description annotations, no value set documentation, no examples, and no relationship documentation. Several fields have empty schemas (Medications, Populations, Race, Ethnicity, etc.) with no type defined. The schema contains typos ('Taxomomy', 'Complience'). While it does define the complete export structure, the quality is low — field names are the sole documentation. The data dictionary link is currently dead (404), only recoverable from the Wayback Machine.

ehi_coverage.overall_assessment: The export covers the data this specific product stores, which is quality registry and analytics data — not comprehensive clinical EHR data. The product is a QCDR that aggregates data from upstream EHR systems for quality reporting and cost analysis. Its export includes demographics, quality measure results, risk scores, conditions, claims history (diagnosis/procedure codes), immunizations, outcomes, utilization data, and episode-of-care cost analytics. This is appropriate for the product's scope — the b(10) requirement covers 'all EHI that can be stored by the product,' and this product stores registry/analytics data, not primary clinical records. Major categories like secure messages, scheduling, document management, and detailed billing are absent, but the product does not have these capabilities. The main concern is whether the export fully covers what the product stores — the empty Medications and Populations schemas suggest possible gaps even within its own data model.

clinical.evidence: Conditions (condition list), Immunizations (vaccine + dates), PatientRisk (risk score, BMI, smoking, BP), Outcomes (named outcomes with date/value), and HistoryClaims (diagnosis codes DxCode1-8, procedure codes). However, this is aggregated/derived data from upstream EHRs — no progress notes, orders, detailed lab results, or radiology. Medications field exists in schema but has empty definition.

secure_messages.evidence: No messaging capability in the product. No patient portal. Not a gap — the product has no messaging features.

billing_financial.evidence: Episodes section includes cost data (AvgCost, EpisodeCost, CostDifference). HistoryClaims includes procedure codes, modifier codes, and diagnosis codes. However, this is claims analytics data, not primary billing records — no individual claim dollar amounts, payments, adjustments, or insurance billing detail. This is appropriate for a quality registry that analyzes cost patterns rather than managing billing.

insurance_coverage.evidence: Demographics includes a single 'Payor' field (payer name). No detailed insurance plan, eligibility, authorization, or benefit data. The product does not manage insurance — it tracks payer for reporting purposes.

appointments_scheduling.evidence: No scheduling capability. UtilizationProvider tracks aggregate visit counts and date ranges per provider, but not individual appointments. Not a gap — the product has no scheduling features.

documents_images.evidence: No document management or imaging capability in the product. QRDA documents are processed internally for quality reporting but are not patient-facing documents. Not a gap — the product has no document management features.

issues: Data dictionary link is dead (404). The file at client.rojihealthintel.com/helpfiles/ehi-export/patientexport.yml returns 404 and was only recoverable via Wayback Machine (April 2024 snapshot). This is a compliance issue — publicly-linked documentation should be accessible.

Medications and Populations sections in the JSON Schema have empty definitions (no properties) despite being listed as required. It is unclear if these are populated in actual exports or are placeholders.
Export instructions require login: 'Instructions for accessing, using and exporting are available to authorized users in the FAQ.' Only the data dictionary is publicly linked.
JSON Schema has typos ('Taxomomy' for Taxonomy, 'Complience' for Compliance) and uses no description annotations, limiting its value as documentation.
File extension is misleading (.yml for a JSON file), indicating inattention to documentation quality.
Several schema fields (Race, Ethnicity, DateOfDeath, CauseOfDeath) lack type definitions.
products.summary: Roji Clinical Data Registry is a QCDR/quality registry, not an EHR. Its EHI export is a native JSON export of aggregated quality/analytics data including demographics, quality measures, risk scores, conditions, claims history, immunizations, outcomes, and episode cost data. The export appears appropriate for the product's narrow scope, but the documentation quality is poor (dead link, typos, empty schemas, no field descriptions) and some sections appear incomplete.

downloaded_files.description: JSON Schema (draft-07) defining the PatientData export structure. Despite .yml extension, content is JSON. Retrieved from Wayback Machine (snapshot 2024-04-23) because the original URL returns 404.
Full HTML of the vendor's costs/requirements/certification/EHI export page (the mandatory disclosures page). Contains the EHI export section text and link to the data dictionary.

summary: Roji Health Intelligence LLC operates a Qualified Clinical Data Registry (QCDR), not an EHR. The Roji Clinical Data Registry aggregates clinical data from upstream EHR systems for quality measure reporting and cost analytics. Its EHI export is a native JSON export documented via a JSON Schema with 11 top-level sections covering demographics, quality measures, risk scores, conditions, claims history, immunizations, outcomes, and episode cost data. The export is appropriate for the product's narrow scope, but the documentation has significant quality issues: the data dictionary link is dead (404, only recoverable from Wayback Machine), the schema has typos and empty sections, and field-level descriptions are absent.
notes: The registered CHPL URL (/costs-and-limitations/) was renamed to /costs-and-requirements/ via a 301 redirect, likely around September 2024 based on Wayback Machine records. The mandatory_disclosures_url in the CHPL metadata already points to the new URL, but the b(10) export documentation URL still references the old path. The Wayback Machine shows the old URL was active from 2019 through at least 2024. The data dictionary file had only one Wayback snapshot (April 2024), suggesting it may have been accessible for a limited time. The product's certification dates to February 2017 and participates in annual Real World Testing through Drummond.
